snippet: Governments have legitimate reasons to seek user data beyond their territorial reach, and privacy advocates ignore that need at their peril.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Andrew Keane Woods observes that countries around world are increasingly exercising territorial control over Internet and Internet users' data, largely due to concerns about fact that much of Internet data is controlled by United States companies; underscores need for some kind of international agreement to govern Internet surveillance, and, in meantime, urges US companies to make it easier for foreign law enforcement agencies to access data.
lead_paragraph: Governments have legitimate reasons to seek user data beyond their territorial reach, and privacy advocates ignore that need at their peril.

headline.print_headline: For Digital Privacy,  Borders Still Matter
